sectionPoints.content: Focus on grounded movement and walling
If they're dancing around with b-reverse air movement, stuff them out with Nairs
Minimize shielding, except when cornered to avoid side b kills
gHS on platform above them: No
Dair through Platform: PS2 / SBF / BF

items.content: Jab -> Bair: 92+ (FD ledge, DI In)
Ftilt: 111+ (FD ledge, DI In)
DED: 86+ (FD ledge, DI In)
Uthrow: 222+ (FD, DI In)
D-tilt: 59+ NR, 37+ MR
Fair: 11+ NR, 1+ MR
Fthrow: 5+ NR, 0+ MR

sectionPoints.content: Many DKs consider Chrom and Roy one of the more tolerable matchups, as they fight with similar speed and range. It typically lies between **even** and **-1.**

items.content: Solid walling tools
Fantastic advantage state in all forms against Chroy
gSK armor to force them to respect mashing on shield
Solid anti-air punishes against b-reverse platform movement
Cargo Down Throw
Amazing movement
Great frame data
Dangerous ledge trapping
Extremely early kill power, ignoring how DK is supposed to be a superheavy

subpoints.content: Both DK and Chrom / Roy love killing off the sides, whether it be through DK’s Giant Punch and gSK or through Chrom / Roy’s ledge trapping and Double-Edge Dance.

Roy's sweet spot side b at ledge kills just as early as Giant Punch, but they can confirm into it (e.g. with Jab) making it a lot more consistent and threatening than Punch. Because of this, you may still want to ban these stages.
Platforms give them extra mobility and landing options, especially through b-reverse side b, which mitigates their otherwise poor air acceleration
DK doesn't mind fighting against this movement, being able to call it out easily with moves like Nair, but it becomes easier without platforms, especially when cornering them
Even if you don't like playing on FD, at the very least don't waste your ban here. Play to stage control and you'll be surprised at how well you can hold your own there.
Even if you can't pDKO on FD, you can still take their stock at similar percents with walkoff CDT gimps
DK typically prefers wider stages in this matchup due to the ability to dash back and punish jump ins.
Smaller stages force you to rely less on walling, and more on overwhelming them with pressure and stage presence. They can only stay so far away from Dash Attack after all
The former is generally considered more consistent, but other players may naturally prefer the latter
Dk prefers staying primarily grounded in this matchup, to punish jumps with dashing back into an attack like Ftilt, as well as to be able to shield as needed
**Weave in and out of their burst range** of their short hop jump ins, and making yourself a more difficult target to hit.
Mix up your dashes and walks (and maybe even slingshots). Bait their jump ins, and punish accordingly.
he standard anti-swordie walling: **Ftilt, gHS, and Bair** (especially with dash back)

subpoints.title: Chrom and Roy have **poor air acceleration** - even worse than DK’s

items.content: Every time they short hop, they’re quite committed to their initial air drift
The arc you see as they rise will basically be the same for when they land, allowing you to punish their landing with confidence

subpoints.content: Turnaround shield** is super useful to **shield grab** against cross-up Nair

items.content: Charge punch, and stay right outside of your dash attack range, so they’ll feel pressured to do something
The closer you get to them, the less safe they'll feel and more inclined they are to act

subpoints.content: If Roy is hopping out, platform camping and bouncing around with b-reverse side b movement... just **Nair**
They also want to use this as bait a whiff with their 'ambiguous' movement, so don't always go for it as soon as you see it
Like anything else it's all a matter of pattern recognition and noticing tempos

subpoints.title: While we're all aware of how powerful a walkoff CDT is against Roy, undestand the following before going for that grab:

items.content: Don’t go for raw dash grabs, unless you've truly conditioned them to shield in bad spots
Pivot grabs can catch their jump in aerials if well-spaced
Dtilt trips are the perfect opportunity to land a grab, especially if you Dtilt their jump in
Parrying aerials can typically land you a grab

subpoints.content: Hihg air speed means goos directional air dodge, which helps his recovery trmendously
If he's forced to use it near the blast zone, go out there as soon as you launch him, and punish that horrendous air dodge cooldown

subpoints.title: Chrom adn Roy have plenty of ways to set up tech chases, inluding

items.content: Dtilt
Aerials
Fthrow

subpoints.title: Try to di up and then a-land

items.content: From there you can mix your options after: shield, spot dodge, jab, etc
Roy's extra hitlag on sweetp spots make DIing up consistent
Fthrow

subpoints.title: When do you have to tech

items.content: Pay attention to your tech optinos (when you do have to tech)
Pay attention to how the opponent is trying to read you
Keep in mind stage positioning when picking and option (and avoiding the worst case scenario, e.g. if roll to ledge will get you killed to roll center won't)
Most Roys are th most prepared for a neutral tech / missed tech, so try to avoid this unless they have a habit / have been conditionend to look for a different option
Roy can set up tech chases more easily than Chrom thanks to sour hits extending tech chase windows

subpoints.title: Ledge hang is really strong specifically vs Roy

items.content: This point is irrelevant however if the opponent knows how to ledge trump
The only move that always hits DK's ledge hang is Dsmash2, and that's reactable
Every move that hits DK's ledge hang when he lifts his head up, only gives Roy the sour spot, without comboing into anything

subpoints.title: While Ledge hang itself is generally good, you still want to avoid the ledge with how ealy his side B kills

items.content: Try landing on stage rather than going for the ledge, even if it means taking a few more Uairs

subpoints.title: Be prepated to DI Away on Jab

items.content: Your naturally want to Di in for survival DI, but DI Away here lets you get hit by Roy's sour spot follow-up, wheter it's fair, bair. or side b

subpoints.content: Their CQC and general frame data is amazing, so shielding is dicouraged if you can reposition instead
shielding also leaves you open to side b mixups
However, in bad spots e.g. in the corner, you often want to hold shield, since their grab game is nowhere near as threatening as say side b kill at 50
gSK can be good to get out of tight spots, but keep it a to a minimum given its risks
